Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Polyploidy in Phlox and its effects on diversity
Award.AbstractNarration:
A team of three scientists from Kansas State University, Michigan State University and the Desert Botanical Garden will investigate polyploidy (the condition of having more than one set of chromosomes) and diversity in the plant genus Phlox (Polemoniaceae). The Phlox species P. amabilis, P. nana and P. woodhousei all exhibit variation in ploidy level and occur as diploid (two sets of chromosomes, 2X), tetraploid (4X) and hexaploid (6X) populations in the southwestern United States. Geographic patterns of ploidy level variation will be documented for these groups using flow cytometry and chromosome count data. By combining phylogenetic, population genetic, morphological, and ecological analyses the researchers will infer relationships among populations, reconstruct their origins, estimate patterns of gene flow, investigate the affect of polyploidy on phenotypes, and identify whether particular ploidy types are more commonly associated with different ecological niches. Data from these approaches will also be used to revise the taxonomy of the group.

While polyploidy is considered to play an important role in plant evolution, our current knowledge of ploidy level variation relative to diversity is limited. This project investigates questions of general interest on polyploidy and diversity and integrates findings to advance a broader understanding of the role of polyploidy in the diversification of plants. Educational modules relating incorporating this research will be developed for public school and botanical garden audiences, and participants from the undergraduate to postdoctoral level will benefit from training and collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Polyploidy in Phlox and its effects on diversity” was funded from 2013-2017 and was a collaborative project between researchers at Michigan State University, Kansas State University, and the Desert Botanical Garden. Most plant species have two sets of chromosomes, but some species exhibit polyploidy and thus have more than two sets. In plants, polyploidy is a common condition in crops. Understanding the role and impacts of polyploidy in natural species will give us insight into how polyploidy affects diversity in nature. We set out to understand if, and how,  polyploidy drives diversification in three closely related species of Phlox from Western North America.

Accomplishments from our collaborative research include:

A better understanding of the role of polyploidy in natural systems. We learned that polyploidy is surprisingly common in all three species, with about one half or more of all populations we sampled consisting of polyploid plants. However, the pattern of distribution varied among species. For instance, in one species we found diploids (plants with the typical two sets of chromosomes) geographically separated from tetraploids (with four sets). Hexaploids (six sets) were very rare in this species. In both the other species, diploids and tetraploids populations had broadly overlapping distributions. In one of those species, the hexaploids were isolated and in the other species they were overlapping with the diploids and tetraploids. We learned that polyploidy plays a major role in the size and proportions of plant features like pollen grains and leaves. Some of the features, like stomata (pores in the leaf epidermis where gas exchange occurs) were affected in a similar way in each species. But some traits were affected in one species but not in others, suggesting that the effects of polyploidy are not entirely predictable.  

A plethora of collections, DNA and tissue samples, and data sets to enable future research. Scientific products included collections of plants deposited in herbaria; leaf, flower, and pollen samples; DNA extractions; and data sets documenting chromosome number, physical measurements of plants, and environmental features from the places where these plants grow.

Informing the public about our research. During the course of this research we worked with public school teachers in Kansas to address how our research could be used to teach about biodiversity in science classrooms during our “Phlox Institute” and developed a teaching module to facilitate that work. We also held a workshop at the Desert Botanical Garden showing the education staff, docents, and interested public how our work related to biodiversity in the southwestern U.S.

Informing other scientists about our work. MSU researchers on this project collaborated on multiple poster and oral presentations at scientific meetings, peer-reviewed journal articles, deposited data sets in public repositories, and the principle investigator gave two invited seminars at other universities.

Training the next generation of scientists. At MSU, one graduate student wrote and defended his thesis on a part of this project. Another graduate student was supported, in part, by this grant while she assisted in the statistical training of project personnel. Over a dozen undergraduates were employed to work on various aspects of the project and all received training in responsible conduct of research and various techniques and skills.
